text: And then -- suddenly -- everything is quiet and peaceful. The sun rises over a distant ridge, revealing a lonely RA nestled in the valley far below. This place feels safe and remote; a tiny island in an oce of green, far away from the horrors of the world.

FRANK SULLIVAN (45) wakes up and slowly climbs out of bed struggles at first; stiff and sore. Once a rugged cowboy, Frank is now approaching middle-age in the 20th century; Man used up and no longer relevant. But there is power in him, yet. A lifetime of farming has left his body in better shape than most men half his age. Frank makes his way through the quiet house; sad and lon PICTURES of his FAMILY (wife, daughter, & son) decorate e room and line every hallway. But they are nowhere to be s Frank Sullivan is all alone.

Frank brews a pot of coffee and fixes some breakfast, listening to the silence as it weighs heavy all around... In a nearby window, a GOLD STAR BANNER shines brightly in morning sun; a timeless symbol of sacrifice and loss. In addition, two BLACK SILK CREPES hang over the front do letting us know death has visited this house recently. And on more than one occasion.

Frank is hard at work, repairing a broken fence. Each ham strike echoes and fades, the only sound for miles... Frank suddenly hears a distant rumbling. He slowly looks A MODEL-T FORD appears over the hill, bouncing along at t miles an hour. Frank squints, recognizing the driver--
For God's sake... The car pulls over and comes to a stop. TOM DONOVAN (40s) climbs out, wearing a sheriff's uniform--
Heya, Frank...
Finally bought one, huh?
Nah, belongs to the city. Being mayor has its perks. You should come into town more often. They outnumber horses, now.
That’s not something I care to see. (Then, noticing) What’s with the uniform? Tom glances at his shirt as he pops the trunk of his car.  Tom bends
Oh, yeah...guess you wouldn’t have heard. I took over for Bill Stevens after he passed.
You're the sheriff, now?
Just until they find a replacement.
I didn’t realize it was legal to hold two public offices.
It probably isn’t. over and lifts out a large BIRTHDAY PRESENT--
What the hell is that?
Think I’d forget?
Think I need a reminder?
You know, a simple ‘thank you’ would do. This isn’t the easiest place to get to. Frank nods and reluctantly takes the package-- Tom shuts
It’s heavy...
Yeah, it’s a nice gift, Frank. the trunk and turns to face his friend. BEAT.
You drove all the way up here just to give me this?
Seemed like a good time to stop by, see how you’re doing...
And how am I doing?
I don’t know. You tell me. Frank hesitates, not sure what to say.
You wanna cup of coffee before heading back?
(a moment, then) Sure, that’d be great.

Frank sets the birthday present down on the kitchen count and starts to brew another pot of COFFEE... Tom stands nearby, his eyes quietly roaming-- He sees the GOLD STAR BANNER hanging in the window. And t black SILK CREPES draped across the front door... And then Tom notices a MILITARY SWORD mounted in a glass case; sheathed and locked away...from an era long ago--
‘Get that in Cuba? Frank looks up as he pours some coffee. Finally, he nods-
‘Thought so. You ever hear from any of the old guys? Frank shakes his head as he walks across the room...
Me, neither. Too bad. I hear Roosevelt’s not doing well. (Takes the coffee) Thanks... Tom takes a sip and nearly spits it out--
God, that’s awful...
I know. I don’t make it as good as Emily used to. Tom hesitates, then takes another sip...this time without complaint. He nods at the birthday present--
C’mon, open it. Frank takes a deep breath and tears away the wrapping pap ...-revealing a brand new VICTROLA PHONOGRAPH--

You seen these things? Everyone's got ‘em. Here, let me show you... Tom places a RECORD on the wheel and lowers the needle... Softly, suddenly-- MUSIC FILLS THE HOUSE It floats down empty hallways and creeps into vacant room hanging gently in the air beside pictures and portraits o people who have left, never to return. Frank’s eyes well with emotion--
Emily and I used to dance to this.

I know. Thought you’d like it. Got ya some others, too... Tom hands over a collection of RECORDS. Frank shuffles through the titles, stopping at one in particular-- AFTER YOU'VE GONE by Marion Harris Frank stares at the record, suddenly overwhelmed. He look at his friend and finally says--
Thank you, Tom. Tom slowly nods as the song comes to an end. He carefully lifts the needle and silence fills the room.
What’s new in town?

You mean besides the horseless carriage? A lot, actually. Most of the construction that was going on before the flu hit started up again. Think the car’s impressive? You should see some of these buildings that are going up. The world’s changing before our very eyes. I still can’t believe it...
‘Quarantine lifted?
Yeah, couple months ago. Stores are back in business. Church is in session. Even re-opened the school. (Off Frank’s look) Rosaleigh’s teaching class until they find a replacement.
It's always amazing to see how quickly people move on...
Nobody's forgotten Emily, Frank. The kids tell Rosaleigh everyday how much they miss her. Frank slowly nods, then finds the courage to ask--
How’s the rest of your family?
(Hesitates) They're fine. Everyone's fine. I was about scared to death when Rosaleigh got sick, but...she pulled through. ‘Seems to be getting stronger everyday. And Edward's due in on Sunday...
(a moment, then) That’s great, Tom. Really.
Eh, we got lucky. I’m just glad the troubles are over.
It’s what we were all praying for.
Yeah... Tom glances at the GOLD STAR BANNER hanging in the window And the SILK CREPES draped across the front door...
..-it’s just too bad it couldn't have happened a little sooner.
Frank walks Tom back to his Model-T Ford. A cold wind blo through the valley. Tom winces, Frank does not.
You know...we’re having a little celebration tonight. Dancing. Fireworks. Should be a good time. No flu masks allowed... (Beat) You should come. Frank glances up at the cloud-riddled sky--
You may be in for some rough weather...
Yeah, well...rain or shine, folks would still love to see ya. (Off Frank’s look) C'mon, no one should be alone on their birthday.
I’m not much good around people these days, Tom.
(Disappointed) Alright. It’s an open invitation, in case you change your mind. Frank watches his friend climb back into his car...
Tell Rosaleigh I said thank you for the thoughtful gift.
Tell her yourself. She'll be there tonight. Just think about it, okay? Frank hesitates, then finally nods. Tom starts the engine puts his car in gear...and slowly drives away.

The wind blows, rattling branches like skeleton bones. Frank is back at work, torquing a hammer to remove a set rusty nails...the hammer's shaft suddenly snaps! Frank falls to the ground with a dull thud. He sits up, himself off...and stares down at his broken tool.

Frank pulls open the door and steps inside. A torrent of excited rustling erupts in the stall up ahead... Frank grabs a SADDLE and walks over to his HORSE, its tai swishes back and forth in hopeful anticipation...
Hey, Fella... Frank strokes the animal’s mane, wondering aloud--
What do you say? Should we go see what’s new in town? The horse’s dark milky eyes give him the answer--

Frank soars across the empty landscape, an expert rider comfortable being a spec in God’s country... But then, suddenly, he brings his horse to a stop-- The wind blows, carrying sounds of a modern town just bey the ridge. Frank hesitates, intimidated... He slowly rides over the hill, revealing--

A world transformed by asphalt and steel. Buildings are reaching skyward, automobiles outnumber horses... Frank takes it all in as he makes his way into town. His horse sidesteps awkwardly, weaving between cars...

PATRONS fill a modern bar, wearing faded jeans and cotton shirts; as well as a few lingering FLU MASKS... CHARLIE FOSTER and BEN SANDERFORD (40s, both “regulars”) up as Frank passes by their window...
You see that? Ben shrugs, dumbfounded. Couldn't be...could it?

ELI PETERSON (60s) sits at his desk, quietly working. Something outside suddenly catches his eye... Eli sets down his pen and goes to the window. His eyes fi with stoic pain as he watches Frank ride into town...

ROSALEIGH DONOVAN (40s, Tom’s wife) stands before THIRTY STUDENTS, writing a lesson on the CHALKBOARD... From the corner of her eye, Rosaliegh sees Frank’s reflec in the window. The chalk in her hands suddenly breaks...
Mrs. Donovan? Are you alright? Rosaleigh walks across the room, as if floating on eggshe She peers quietly out the window. And then--
Look! It’s Mrs. Sullivan’s husband! The entire class rushes to the window--

NATHAN MILLER (18, town deputy) comes walking down the st with a brand new BOOK tucked under his arm... PATRICK BONNER (32, town deputy) waits outside the sherif office. He sees his partner approaching and nods--
What ya got there? Nathan smiles and holds up the FRONT COVER-- ATTACK OF TH
PATRICK (CONT’D) God, not another one. How many of those stupid things ya gonna buy?

I dunno. I was too young for the draft. Sounds pretty exciting... Nathan starts flipping through the pages. Suddenly, Patri gives him an urgent nudge. The young deputy looks up-- Frank Sullivan rides by on his horse. The two deputies st dumbfounded. Then, suddenly, they hear a voice from behin  10.
What the hell’s going on out here? Patrick and Nathan both turn to face Tom Donovan. BEAT.
Hey, Sheriff...or do you still want us to call you ‘Mr. Mayor’?

Hell, Nathan, I don’t know. You ask me that every day. Just call me Boss, alright? (Confused) What’s everyone looking at? (Then, seeing Frank) Well, shit. That didn’t take long. INT. LEONARD DUSCHENE’S APARTMENT -- SAME TIME LEONARD DUSCHENE (28) stands in the gloomy shadows of his tiny bedroom, a haunted man living in exile-- He watches Frank stop just outside the SUNDRY STORE...
Frank glances briefly at a SILK CREPE hanging in the wind then opens the door and steps cautiously inside--

PROPAGANDA POSTERS still hang on the wall, looming above stacks of RED BARON NOVELS trumpeting the glory of war... Frank ignores them as he heads down the aisle. He grabs a HAMMER off the shelf and walks over to the counter... KAY ANDERSON (40s, store owner) watches Frank approach. S smiles sadly through warm, gentle eyes--
Will that be everything, Frank?
Hello, Kay...got a newspaper that’s current? Kay nods and slides one across the counter. Frank glances the BOLD HEADLINE-- ARMISTICE DECLARED; PEACE AT LAST!
‘Guess I don’t have to ask if you want to buy war bonds, huh?  11. Frank slowly shakes his head. Kay rings up his total--
That’1ll be sixty-seven cents. Frank hands her a DOLLAR BILL and waits for change...
You running the store, now?
Yeah, since Daniel passed. It’s been hard. But Spencer’s coming home soon. So at least I have that to look forward to... (Then, changing subjects) ‘Coming to the celebration tonight?
No...don’t think so.

Oh, that’s a shame... (As she bags his things) May be best, though. They’re saying a big storm’s heading our way... Frank smiles politely and reaches for the bag. Kay sudden tightens her grip, refusing to let go--

I’m sorry about your boy. Your wife and daughter, too. It just ain’t fair...what happened to you. Frank slowly nods, then backs away and reaches for the do He glances out the window and suddenly stops-- SUE FOWLER (40) is outside, walking down the street...

She’s a vision of grace and loveliness, greeting everyone with a smile as she makes her way through town... Sue Fowler has no idea that she’s being followed. Twenty yards back, across the street, Frank Sullivan walk his footsteps in line with hers -- watching her every mov
Sue Fowler, now dressed in a WHITE DOCTOR’S COAT, comes o of the examination room with REVEREND MORGAN FARLEY (50s)  12.
I wouldn't worry about it, Morgan. Should clear up in a week or two.
Thanks, Sue. I can always count on you to put my mind at ease.
It’s not the flu.
God, what a relief... They turn a corner and suddenly stop dead in their tracks shocked to see Frank Sullivan standing near the door--
Frank...I didn’t hear you come in. Have you been here long?
Not really. (To Reverend Farley) How are you, Morgan?

I’m well, Frank. And you? Frank hesitates, then shrugs. Farley steps closer-- REVEREND FARLEY (CONT’D) I don’t believe we've seen each other since your wife and daughter passed. Frank...I am so sorry. If there’s anything I can do--
There isn’t...but thank you. Reverend Farley hesitates, then turns back to Sue--
I’1l see you on Sunday, then?
(Nods ) Bye, Morgan. Reverend Farley tips his hat and leaves. The door closes softly behind him. Frank and Sue are alone. BEAT.
What are you doing here?  13.
I was in town. Thought I’d stop by.
(a moment, then) It’s good to see you.
Reverend Farley comes outside and walks down the street. sees Tom Donovan up ahead and goes over to meet him--
You're never gonna believe who I just saw in Sue Fowler’s office.
Frank Sullivan. (Off Farley’s look) ‘Saw him ride in.

I can’t even imagine... (Looks up at Sue’s window) ..-he lost everyone. Tom slowly nods, then glances down the street where a LAR BANNER is being hung above the TOWN’S ENTRANCE... REVEREND FARLEY (CONT’D) How’s the new job treating you?
Eh, fair enough. I just hope things stay quiet.
I’m sure they will, Tom. After everything we’ve been through. (Beat) What could possibly happen, now? Tom turns and gives Farley a look: don’t tempt fate.

Frank sits on a table with his shirt unbuttoned. Sue warm her STETHOSCOPE and places it over his chest... This office, like everything else in town, reflects a wor in transition; the old giving way to the new. X-RAYS and MICROSCOPES, VACCINES and ASPIRIN BOTTLES...al mingle with crude instruments from an earlier time.  14.
Take a deep breath... (Frank inhales/exhales) How have you been feeling?
Fine, I guess.

Any symptoms I should be worried about. Fever? Headaches? Frank slowly shakes his head as Sue listens to his heartb their faces just inches apart. Sue suddenly pulls away-- SUE (CONT’D) Roll up your sleeve, please. Frank tugs at the arm of his shirt. Sue wraps a BLOOD PRESSURE CUFF around his bicep...
‘Hear your nephew’s coming home...
My sister tell you that?
Yeah, just saw her. Sue squeezes the pump, tightening around Frank’s arm...

You know, I was pretty heartbroken when George and I realized we couldn’t have children. But watching all those mothers send their boys off to war...I don’t know...made me feel like maybe it was a blessing in disguise... (Then, off Frank’s look) I’m happy for her. She could use a little joy. We all could... Sue checks the redial and unfastens the cuff-- SUE (CONT’D) Congratulations, you’re in better shape than most teenagers.
I bet you say that to all your patients.  15. Sue smiles and begins to put her things away...
Are you worried about anything in particular, Frank? Frank shrugs, something clearly on his mind. Sue glances the WEDDING BAND on his right ring finger--
How long has it been?
(a moment, then) Almost a year. Sue steps forward, choosing her words carefully--
I know it’s natural to worry when people you've lived with get sick, but if you’re not showing any symptoms by now, then...
I’m in the clear?
In a manner of speaking. Frank slowly nods. BEAT.
Have there been any recent cases?
Not for awhile. Things are getting back to normal. Sore throats. Broken bones. That sort of thing.
Think you'll stay on?

I honestly don’t know. We’ll see what happens when the boys come home. It’s one thing for a nurse to take over when all the male doctors have been drafted. Or killed. But making it permanent is something else entirely. Frank glances across the room, where a portrait of the to late PHYSICIAN (60s) still hangs on the wall. BEAT.  16.
You should stay. People know you, trust you...you’re good at it.

Thank you, Frank. They sit together in silence and the tension quickly retu Suddenly, the sound of distant SINGING fills the air... Frank and Sue stand up and go to the window-- A group of CIVIL WAR VETERANS (all 70s) are standing outs singing WHEN JOHNNY COMES MARCHING HOME; Written by a different generation fighting a different wa the lyrics seem as timely as ever. These dying veterans - their voices old, but resolute -- bear witness to the mos universal of truths: Dwell on the past and you'll lose an eye. Forget the past and you'll lose both. SUE (CONT’D) I remember when you left with President Roosevelt all those years ago. We sang the same song, then. We've really been through a lot, haven't we? An epidemic and a war .--all in the same year.
It’s the way it’s always been... Frank stares out the window and sees Eli Peterson on the street. Once again, we sense the two men have history...

When I was in the Philippines, we lost six men to measles for every one we lost in combat. Soldiers sleep in close quarters. They board trains. They travel all over the world. If you want to spread a disease...all you need is a war. Frank notices the LARGE BANNER being hung at the edge of town. Then he shifts his glance to a familiar building--
How’s Leonard doing?
He stays in his room most days. And that seems to suit people just fine. They’re still pretty angry.  17.
It wasn’t his fault.

I know. But it’s always easier when there’s someone to blame. I feel sorry for him...he’s got nobody. Frank glances at Sue, then stares back out the window. BE SUE (CONT’D) Is it lonesome living all by yourself? I don’t mean to pry, it’s just...I imagine the solitude would be pretty hard to bear.
It’s not so bad...once you get used to the feeling.
You don’t live so far away. I could cook you a meal sometime, if you’re inclined to accept an invitation...
George okay with that?
(Hesitates) He’d love to have you. Frank smiles, knowing that’s not true. He glances out the window once more, then cautiously steps back--
I should go.

It was good to see you. Don’t wait so long next time. Frank smiles, then steps forward and gives Sue a gentle h goodbye. She suddenly winces in pain... Frank hesitates, then pulls at her neckline...revealing a mottling grey bruise just beneath her shoulder blade.
Goddamnit.
Frank, please.  18.
I thought he quit that. Sue pulls away and covers herself...
He didn’t know he was hurting me, alright? He started drinking again when his brother died. (then, off Frank’s look) You’re not the only one who’s lost someone, you know...
Sue...
Frank, it’s none of your business. Just let it be... She steps back, folds her arms...and finally looks at him
Will there be anything else?
No, I guess not. Frank slowly turns and heads for the door. Sue watches hi wishing he wouldn’t leave like this--
Frank? Frank stops and looks back at her. Sue hesitates, then sa
Happy Birthday. Frank smiles, softly. Then turns...and leaves.

Frank climbs back on his horse just as the LARGE BANNER i unfurled above the town’s entrance-- It's a triumphant declaration heralding the end of war, a well as the heroic return of the town's soldier sons. Frank stares at it for a moment. And then, suddenly, he realizes everyone is watching him... Frank takes a final look at the singing veterans. Then El Peterson. And then, finally, his friend Tom Donovan.  19. Frank kicks his horse swiftly and gallops away, passing beneath the banner as he rides out of town...

Frank comes to a beautiful clearing and tethers his horse a nearby tree. The wind blows, cold and ominous-- Frank takes a deep breath, summoning his courage. He plac handkerchief over his face...and enters the town cemetery And now we get a glimpse of the true horror of influenza; freshly dug GRAVES and unburied CASKETS stacked row upon HEADSTONES mark the remains of young and old, rich and po .--all dying in the dreaded plague year of 1918. Frank makes his way through this awful place, finally stopping at the graves of his wife and daughter. He stares at his family -- helpless and alone.

Dozens of MODEL-T FORDS park along the meadow’s edge; the bright headlights piercing the dusty haze of twilight. TOWNSPEOPLE welcome each other as the BAND starts to play MUSIC fills the air. Everyone claps and cheers... It’s going to be an eventful evening.

Frank sits in the dark shadows of his lonely house, liste to Marion Harris sing AFTER YOU'VE GONE on the phonograph Now won't you listen honey, while I say / How could you t me that you're going away? / Don't say that we must part Don't break your baby's heart... As the song continues, Frank takes a pair of SCISSORS and clips the front page of the newspaper he bought earlier.. The flickering light of a nearby candle dances in his eye Frank stares at a headline that seems to taunt him--

Frank glances at the GOLD STAR. And the song continues-- After you've gone...and left me crying / After you've gon there's no denying / You'll feel blue, you'll feel sad / You'll miss the dearest pal you've ever had--  20. Overwhelmed, Frank lifts the needle and the song abruptly stops. The house grows deathly quiet. But then-- A crack of THUNDER suddenly rumbles overhead. And the aut wind carries the faint sound of distant celebration... Frank Sullivan stands up and goes to the window. BEAT.

The party is in full swing. The band plays to the sunset rows of dancing couples welcome the night-- Nearby, a group of men prepare some FIREWORKS, waiting fo darkness so they can rocket them into the sky... As the music pools with laughter and joy, a few TOWNSPEOP notice the approaching sound of GALLOPING HORSE HOOVES... Heads turn as they draw near. Then, suddenly-- Frank Sullivan appears over the ridge, riding towards the his reluctance visible even from a distance. TOWNSPEOPLE gasp, a few nudge each other and point. Frank tethers his horse to a tree at the end of a long li of MODEL-T FORDS. The animal snorts with disgust--

Don’t worry. I won’t be long. Frank turns and approaches the crowd. TOWNSPEOPLE come ov to say ‘hello’. Frank smiles, shaking everybody's hand... Sue Fowler watches from a distance-- She’s dressed for the occasion and looks even lovelier th before. A little makeup has put a spotlight on her face. Frank Sullivan notices her right away. Sue's breathing grows heavy as he approaches; her body language a curious mixture of excitement and fear. She waits for him to reach her...and then finally says--
I’m glad you came.

Yeah, well... (Looks around) It is my birthday, after all.  21. Sue smiles as the world celebrates around them. The last vestiges of twilight fade and the sky grows very dark... But neither Sue nor Frank notice. They’re lost in each ot
Rosaleigh grabs Tom by the arm, nodding at Frank and Sue-

Would you look at that... (Tom follows her gaze) I wonder how much shorter George’s leash will get now that Emily Sullivan is dead and buried. Tom glances at his wife with mild disappoval. And then Rosaleigh shifts her glance...and suddenly freezes-- Leonard Duschene is walking along the meadow's edge...
I don’t see how he can even show his face...after all the misery he brought on this town. Aren't they supposed to hang traitors? Tom stares at Leonard...and slowly nods.
Frank and Sue continue to talk--
That's quite a dress.
Oh, I’ve had it for years.
Looks brand new.
I don’t get to wear it that often «--do you like it?

(a moment, then) Very much. Frank glances at the dancing couples, then looks back at We can see in his eyes what he’d like to ask her. And we can tell by hers that she’s dying to say yes.  22. But Frank is torn both by loyalty and concern over what people might think. He fidgets nervously with the wedding ring on his finger...and hesitates a moment too long--
Well, look who it is... GEORGE FOWLER (40) steps forward, holding a beer in his h Frank's eyes slant to stab wounds. Sue tenses, on edge.
How are ya, Frank?
Fine, George. Yourself?
Pretty good. Frank clenches his fist and glances at Sue. She stares at him, begging with her eyes: Not here. Not now.
‘Sorry about Dave.
Yeah, he deserved better. Hell, I suppose we all did. (Glances up at the sky) Wonder how much longer the weather’s gonna hold...
Hopefully they’1ll be able to get the fireworks off in time. George slowly nods, then turns to Sue--

C’mon...let’s go over and say ‘hi’ to the Ludlows. (As they leave) See ya around, Frank. Frank watches George and Sue head back into the crowd, th he slowly turns...and sees Tom Donovan standing nearby--
That new job of yours come with any deputies?
Yeah, two of ‘em. ‘Only men left in this town under the age of forty.  23.
You need to take ‘em out and pay George Fowler a visit... (Off Tom’s look) He’s drinking again.
Last I checked, that’s not against the law. Not yet, anyway. His brother died. Cut him a break.
‘Problem is when George Fowler drinks, he gets violent. (Off Tom’s look) Sue’s got bruises around her shoulder and collar bone.
Who told you that?
Saw it with my own eyes. Tom glances across the meadow, letting out a deep sigh--
Shit. I was worried about that. There have been rumors...
Why hasn’t anything been done?
What am I supposed to do?
I don’t know, Sheriff. You tell me.
Hey, take it easy. I’11 look into it, alright? Frank stares at Tom as THUNDER erupts overhead...

Don’t look at me like that. I told you I hate this goddamn job... Tom suddenly turns and disappears back into the crowd. Fr watches him go, then heads the other way... As he walks, Frank overhears PARENTS asking each other wh their children are coming home from the war...  24. Frank looks away, saddened. He glances across the meadow. and sees Leonard Duschene standing all by himself-- The two men stare at each other for a moment...and then t sound of MICROPHONE FEEDBACK causes everyone to look up. Tom Donovan and Reverend Farley are standing at the PODIU
Ladies and Gentlemen...could I have everyone’s attention, please? The music and dancing stop. All eyes turn to Tom--

As most of you probably know by now, I’m no good at making speeches. But I wanted to welcome you all out tonight...and just say thank you for coming. (Applause, then) This is a time for celebration. But we would be remiss if we did not pause to remember those we’ve lost this past year. So, on that note, I'd like to turn it over to Reverend Farley. Morgan? Reverend Farley steps forward. The mood turns grim--

In memory of the fallen, I ask that we observe a moment of silence... Suddenly, CHILDREN and TEENAGERS begin roaming through th crowd, holding trays filled with SMALL CANDLES... REVEREND FARLEY (CONT’D) Members of our Sunday school will be passing by with candles. Please take one for every family member you lost this year, whether it was from sickness...or war. TOWNSPEOPLE start taking candles as the children pass by. Every FAMILY takes at least one; some even take two. A soft orange glow slowly spreads through the meadow... Frank Sullivan looks up at a YOUNG GIRL standing before h He takes a deep breath and picks up a candle... Then, with his other hand, he picks up two more.  25.
Eli Peterson watches Frank struggle to hold three candles his own. With trembling hands, Eli sets his candle down.

Reverend Farley lifts a single flame high above his head. The entire town follows his lead. Hundreds of flames rise the darkness, whispering gently in the faint autumn air. Leonard stares at all the candles, haunted and guilt-ridd Everyone observes a moment of silence. And then Reverend Farley takes a deep breath...and blows out his flame. Everyone else does likewise. The meadow suddenly goes dar A devastating stillness hangs in the air...and then the s of SHRIEKING ROCKETS causes everyone to look up-- FIREWORKS explode overhead. TOWNSPEOPLE gasp and applaud, their faces fading up and down with the flickering light. Then, softly and suddenly-- Distant GUNSHOTS pop in the faraway woods...

They reverberate for a moment and quickly die away, absor by the loud explosions booming overhead. Frank is the only one who notices. He turns and looks out the thick dark trees, wondering if he heard right...

Frank Sullivan’s ranch sits peacefully in the night... A gust of wind shakes the trees like a torrent of darknes followed by rumbling thunder and flashes of lightning. The storm warnings subside and the silence returns. A cal soothing moment hangs in the air...and then-- A YOUNG WOMAN (20s) stumbles out of the woods; her clothe soaking wet, her body drenched in blood. The sight of her should take our breath away. She appears suddenly out of nowhere, like a ghost in the darkness. She limps towards Frank Sullivan's house...  26.

The young woman breaks a window and comes inside, leaving thick trail of blood with every painful step. She searches frantically for medicine and supplies, but t house is very dark. And her life is fading fast. She collapses on the floor with a sickening thud; unconsc and near death, her blood pooling around her. Outside, a violent crack of thunder promises heavy rain..

Just as the fireworks conclude, the DOWNPOUR begins... Everybody runs to their cars, but the Model-Ts are trappe Engines start and wheels spin. Nobody is able to get away ...except for Frank, who walks calmly towards his horse - kicking and snorting beneath an onslaught of rain... Frank climbs into the saddle and gallops away, passing sc of cars as they fishtail in vain.

Frank comes inside and takes off his wet coat. He lights candle and makes his way through the dark house... Suddenly, Frank stops. He can hear the storm outside loud than ever. He sees the broken window first... .+-and then he steps in something wet. Frank kneels, holding the candle close to the floor. His suddenly widen -- he’s standing in a pool of blood. A burst of LIGHTNING reveals the young girl on the floor. Frank springs to action, reacting on pure instinct-- He picks the girl up and sets her down on the kitchen tab knocking everything to the ground in order to make room.. He tears off her clothes and finds three bullet wounds; t in the arm, one in the thigh. Blood pours out of her body Frank wraps a tourniquet above each wound, then finds the girl's pulse...so faint, it’s barely even there. Frank stares at her, overwhelmed. This is as far as his knowledge will take him. He needs help. He needs...a doct  27.

Frank gallops through the pouring rain, weaving between trapped cars and foggy headlight beams-- He knocks on windows and waits for them to crack. Then he peers inside, hoping to find Sue Fowler... Finally, Frank reaches the right car. He knocks loudly an waits. The window opens...George Fowler peers out--
Frank? What the hell...? Frank rides around to the other side of the car. He knock the window...it immediately rolls down--
What’s wrong?

My husband died eight months ago when the flu spread through town. Two days later, I watched my only son march off to war... (Gathering herself) And every night since then, I’ve prayed for just one thing. That my boy would come back to me...alive. (Beat) He’s due in next Thursday. Kay stares at Frank for moment, then--

You and my sister did right in trying to help this girl. Nobody faults you for that. It was Christian charity, fine and decent. (Beat) But when you killed those men today, you invited the devil back into our town. It’s your mistake, not ours. And we shouldn’t have to pay for it. I’m begging you... (Beat) Let this cup pass from us.  84. Kay slowly sits down. Frank turns to face everyone--

What would you have me do? Wheel her out into the street so we can all close our windows and pretend we don’t hear the gunfire? (Looks up at Farley) Should we put the girl in God's hands and call it a day?
There are worse hands to be in, Frank. Much worse.
That may be. But it wasn’t so long ago that you wouldn’t even set foot in our cemetary to conduct a funeral. You remember? Because I do. Sometimes God’s hands are no match against fear...

You think I’m a coward, Frank? Is that it? You think we’re all cowards? Well, maybe we are... (Beat) But I will tell you this: our community has been through the darkest of nights. Look around you. Maybe you'll be struck, as I am, by all the people who aren’t here. (Points to various people) Ella-May lost her husband of fifty- three years. Mary Richardson lost her new baby boy. The Fuller’s son died at Verdun; the Cooper’s boy at Belleau Wood. The Stevenson’s graciously adopted the three Randall children after both their parents were killed. (Beat) There isn’t a single family here who hasn’t been touched by the tragedy of the past year. And now, just when the sun is finally starting to rise... (Holds up one of the gruesome photographs) You want us to head back into the shadows and face something we don’t understand. It’s asking a lot.  85.

I know, but I’m not the one asking. (Turns to face everyone) I didn’t ask for any of this. Not for my wife to perish or my children to die. Not for sickness. Not for war. And certainly not for this girl... (Beat) But I can’t just sit back and let harm come to her. I’m surprised anyone here can...considering everything we’ve been through. (Beat) Don’t you understand? If we turn away from this now...we’ll never survive it. Frank stares at a sea of blank faces...

Isn’t there someone here who wants to stand up and say no more? When did we become the sort of people who peer out of windows and hide behind locked doors? That’s not us. That’s not who we are. (Beat) Who will stand up with me? Frank glances around the room...and starts to call names-
Bob?...Thomas?...Ralph?...Earl? Each man reluctantly shakes his head...
Charlie?...Ben? Both men shake their heads. Frank turns to his father-in-
Eli? Eli Peterson stares at Frank with blank eyes...
We're family.
We were. Frank takes a deep breath, turning to one last person--  86.
Tom? Tom glances at his wife and son, then looks down...ashame
What if it was your daughter? Tom slowly shakes his head with tears in his eyes--
It’s not. Edward stares at his father. Rosaleigh trembles in her se
What’s wrong with you? All of you?! This is basic right and wrong... Rosaleigh can’t take it anymore. She suddenly erupts--
Damnit, Frank, it’s easy for you to say...we have something to live for. You don’t! The room plunges to silence. It’s an awful thing say...bu Rosaleigh can’t take it back--

Is that what you think? (Then, to everyone) Is that what all of you think? Nobody responds or even looks Frank in the eye. They just stare at their hands...as if idly passing the time. Frank slowly puts on his hat...and walks out of the churc

Frank comes outside and stares at the empty street; imagi what will be like to face gunmen all by himself... A cold wind suddenly blows, dark and ominous; rattling th window panes like a harbinger of doom. Frank walks towards Sue’s clinic... INT. DOCTOR’S OFFICE -- MAIN FLOOR -- MOMENTS LATER Frank comes inside and heads for the stairs. He sees Nath TIN STAR on the counter...and reluctantly picks it up. BE  87.

Sue and Leonard move quietly through the dark room, picki up the pieces after George’s terrible rampage... The door softly opens and Frank Sullivan comes inside. SHATTERED GLASS crunches beneath his feet... Frank turns on the light-- The room is torn asunder; books and equipment scattered o the floor, two wounded people standing in the shadows... Frank crosses the room and grabs Sue gently by the arm. S resists for a moment, then finally turns around-- Her face is bruised and bloody. Swollen eyes, split lip. Frank has to bite his hand just to keep from screaming--
Frank, please...
Where is he?

I don’t know. It doesn’t matter. It’s over, he’s gone... Frank glances at the girl, expecting the worst-- SUE (CONT’D) She's fine. He didn’t hurt her. Frank, please...don't. Sue collapses into his arms and starts to cry. Frank hesitates, then gently strokes her hair--
Alright...alright. Leonard turns and quietly leaves the room. Frank waits fo the door to shut, then guides Sue over to the couch...
Here, sit down.
TOWNSPEOPLE sit in stunned silence, glancing at each othe the weight of what happened starts to take hold-- A few people begin to stand up...and head for the door.  88.
Frank soaks a COTTON SWAB with ALCOHOL and begins to clea Sue’s wounds. She winces in pain--
Sorry...
It’s okay. Just stings a little. Frank slowly nods...and continues with care.
TOWNSPEOPLE come outside into the cold, grim night. Some linger for a moment, others start to head home...

I don’t know about everyone else, but I could sure use a drink... A few TOWNSPEOPLE follow Charlie towards the saloon... Tom, Rosaleigh, and Edward stand nearby. Edward watches t departing citizens, torn by everything he’s just seen...
We should probably stay in the office tonight... (Off their looks) The walls are reinforced by steel. Rosaleigh stares at her husband, then nods...terrified.

The bartender turns on the lights and discovers George Fo sitting at the counter, nervously rubbing his hands... The bartender hesitates, then sets down a bottle of WHISK George pulls the cork and pours himself a drink...

George? Your hands are bleeding... George looks up as the door opens behind him. Charlie Fos and some other TOWNSPEOPLE begin to trickle inside... George grabs the bottle and flees into the back room... INT. DOCTOR’S OFFICE -- SAME TIME Sue stares at Frank as he quietly treats her wounds...  89.
He wasn’t always like this. Incase you were wondering...
Wondering what?
(a moment, then) Why I married him. A TRAIN WHISTLE suddenly shrieks far in the distance; so faint that Frank and Sue barely seem to notice... SUE (CONT’D) You and Emily ever fight?
On occasion.
Did it ever get...bad? Frank looks at her...and suddenly grasps her meaning--

No. Never. (Beat) It was always over little things. Should we get indoor plumbing? Buy a car? Was Kathryn old enough to date? We argued about the future... (Then, softly) Guess it was pretty silly, considering we didn’t have one. Frank tapes a BANDAGE to Sue’s cheek. They stare at each other for a moment, their faces just inches apart...
Why did you leave me? Frank's eyes flicker, wounded and filled with regret--
I don’t know how to answer that, Sue. I really don’t. Sue takes out the Rough Rider photograph, which she’s kep all this time. She slowly hands it to Frank--
Was it everything they said it was going to be? (MORE )
Roosevelt and his legendary Rough Riders...the adventure of a lifetime? Frank stares at the photograph, ashamed. SUE (CONT’D) I read stories about massacres... one newspaper called it genocide.
That’s one way of putting it... Frank stares at his past self, thinking of his son--
All men fight in wars for the same reason, Sue. It’s a matter of luck whether you get to be on the right side of history or not. Sue points to the young man in the photograph--

You know...every now and then, I think about the boy who left all those years ago...and what life would’ve been like had he stayed. (Beat) I imagine he would’ve been kind. The train whistle suddenly shrieks again; close enough no that Frank and Sue can hear its engine chugging forward.. SUE (CONT’D) Is there going to be more bloodshed? Frank's dark eyes give her the answer-- SUE (CONT’D) You’re certain?
As much as I am that the earth turns.
Is Tom going to help you? Frank hesitates, then slowly shakes his head... SUE (CONT’D) What about the others?  gl. Frank holds up the TIN STAR Nathan abandoned--
I’m all alone on this. Frank sets the badge down and stares at it for a moment.
I never wondered why you married him. I always knew. The only thing I never understood was...why you didn't wait.

Frank, when you left...I was angry. I'm sorry... Frank reaches out and touches her bruised face. Sue leans into his hand as tears trickle down her cheek... Then, in the depths of silence, Frank hears something--
Listen...
What? There’s nothing.
(Dramatic Beat) I know...the train stopped.
TOWNSPEOPLE stare at the distant station, where thick tuf of smoke float into the dark evening sky--

A LONG TRAIN sits on the tracks, lurking ominously in the night like a dark trojan horse. Then, suddenly-- A CAR DOOR bursts open... A MAN (40) steps onto the platform. All alone. Dressed in beautiful suit, wearing confidence like a bullet proof ve He looks around the empty station, smiling at the shadows Then he slowly turns...and walks straight into town--

The man strolls down the street, whistling a familiar tun ("Do Not Forsake Me, Oh My Darling")  92. The melody floats through the air; cheerful and creepy. TOWNSPEOPLE flee into buildings as the stranger approache
PATRONS take cover...
Kay ducks out of view...
Eli Peterson sits at his desk, quietly listening...
Tom, Rosaleigh, and Edward exchange nervous glances...
Farley watches a DARK FIGURE float past his window... INT. LEONARD DUSCHENE’S ROOM -- THAT MOMENT
Leonard slowly turns and opens his bedroom closet. He sta at his WWI UNIFORM...and then pulls out his RIFLE.
The young girl squirms in fear as the whistling comes clo Sue checks her pulse. Frank goes to the window...
The stranger looks up at the WWI BANNER and suddenly stop whistling. Then he smiles...and enters the saloon.
Frank steps away from the window and heads for the door. watches him leave, then glances back at the young girl...
The stranger smiles as PATRONS stand up from behind their tables...and reluctantly sit back down--
You folks expecting a tornado or something? Charlie glances at Ben from the corner of his eye. Everyo else looks away, too frightened to answer...  93.
What’1ll it be, Mister?
Shot of rye, if ya got it. The bartender nods and starts to pour. The stranger glanc over his shoulder, drawing strength from everyone’s fear- STRANGER (CONT’D) Nice town ya got here.
Passing through?
Something like that. The stranger picks up his drink and gulps it down--
Frank Sullivan steps out into the empty street, making hi way towards the saloon...
Tom stares quietly out the window, watching his friend ch through the night towards the unknown...
You going to go over there? Tom glances at his son, unsure. BEAT.
The stranger sets down his empty glass...
Another? The stranger nods, why not? The bartender pours...
Got a doctor around these parts? PATRONS glance nervously at each other... STRANGER (CONT’D) Say you get shot, for example... where would you go?  94.
I really don’t know. I’m the not the person to talk to about that sort of thing. The stranger stares at the bartender and smiles--
What do I owe for the rye?
Thirty cents...
Tell you what... The stranger throws a wad of MONEY on the counter-- STRANGER (CONT’D) I’ll make it a hundred dollars...if you tell me who is the person to talk to about that sort of thing.
I don’t understand...

Oh, I think you do. The bartender shakes his head as the stranger leans forwa focused, unrelenting...refusing to take no for an answer. And then, suddenly, they hear a door open-- Frank Sullivan comes into the bar. He stares at the stran for a moment, then sits down at a nearby table. The stranger glances at the bartender, “Him?” The bartender nods...and pockets the hundred dollars.
Frank listens to the stranger's approaching footsteps and then looks up as a dark shadow falls across his face-- STRANGER (CONT’D) I’m wondering if you could help me?
You don’t look like the sort of man who needs much help. The stranger smiles and sits down--  95.

We all need a little help, especially in a strange town... (Beat) I’m looking for a girl. Medium build. Five and a half feet tall. Fair complexion. Very beautiful. (Beat) Sound like anybody you know? Frank shakes his head as the door opens again. Tom Donova quietly enters, followed by Reverend Farley... STRANGER (CONT’D) I work for some people who are very concerned about her. We have reason to believe she was in the area. Sent a couple men out looking for her, but...they seem to have disappeared.
Maybe they ran off together. Maybe they don’t want to be found...
Well, if that’s the case, it’s even more important that we find them. The girl, at least.
(Confused) What about the men?

As long as we find the girl, we'd be willing to forget about them. Call it an even exchange. (Dramatic Beat) Our men...for your deputy. The stranger sets a BLOOD-STAINED BADGE down on the table STRANGER (CONT’D) You'll be happy to know he was very brave. Didn’t even scream. Said to tell his kids he loved ‘em. Frank glances at Tom, frozen across the room. STRANGER (CONT’D) Is it a matter of money? If not, then what is it? I saw that cemetery when I came in. (MORE )

STRANGER (CONT’D) Pretty crowded. How many able- bodied men could this town possibly have left? Frank slowly looks up, calm and defiant-- STRANGER (CONT’D) Do you have any idea who you’re dealing with? Look what we did ina few short hours. You wired for the feds. Our men showed up, instead. Your telegraph is cut. Your train station is off the map. Don’t you realize how alone you are? Frank stares at the stranger...but doesn’t respond. BEAT. STRANGER (CONT’D) You know...I remember when the flu spread last year, the government sent a dispatch to towns like this. You probably got it... (Quoting) ...”Round up your woodworkers and set them to making coffins. Then round up your street laborers...and set them to digging graves." (Beat) That was all the help you got then. And it’s all you’re getting now. The stranger suddenly reaches into his coat. Everyone ten fearing he’s about to draw a gun... ..-but the stranger takes out a collection of PAPERS, instead. He looks up at Frank, smiling like the devil... STRANGER (CONT’D) Do you know how easy it is to intercept a telegraph? A few snips and a little cut...and the signal gets re-routed. (Holds up first page) From the town of Sparks... Everyone leans forward as the stranger reads--— STRANGER (CONT’D) ...Dear Sheriff, stop. We regret we have no men to send at this time, stop. Very sorry, stop. (Turns the page) From Dawson...Sheriff Donovan, stop. Unable to provide help, stop. (MORE )

STRANGER (CONT’D) Please keep us abreast as the situation unfolds, stop. (Turns the page) From Ridgeview... TOWNSPEOPLE start to look away, sensing the pattern... STRANGER (CONT’D) Have neither resources nor men to Spare, stop. Deeply regret, stop. (Looks up at Frank) «Good luck, stop. The stranger throws the papers down on the table-- STRANGER (CONT’D) You can read the rest for yourself. They all say the same thing. Nobody's coming. Why would they? Frank shuffles through the messages one at a time. The stranger watches, genuinely puzzled-- STRANGER (CONT’D) Why are you doing this? What’s in it for you? Do you even know who you're risking your life for? Frank's eyes flicker faintly with doubt-- STRANGER (CONT’D) You think she’s worth saving? A damsel in distress in need of a white knight? You think by defending her, you'll redeem this town? Maybe even yourself? That you've finally got a cause worth fighting for? Boy...have I got a few surprises for you. (Raising his voice) She's a hooker. Sorry to disappoint you, but...that’s what she is. A two-bit whore. Pay her enough, she'll do anything you want. Fucked the wrong guy, heard the wrong things. And now she’s a nothing witness in a nothing case... (Beat) You're telling me you’re gonna risk your life and lives of all these people to save someone like her? Have you thought this through? Trains and telegraphs are the least we can do. (MORE )

STRANGER (CONT’D) We'll wipe this town off the face of the earth. You’ll see. We're just getting warmed up. The stranger looks around the room as his words take hold STRANGER (CONT’D) Now why don’t you do the sensible thing and mind your own business? This girl has no friends. No family. When she’s gone, there will be no newspaper headlines mourning her death. She won’t have a funeral or even an obituary. Because no one will remember her long enough to forget her. It’ll be as though she never existed. All you have to do is order another drink and try not to worry about things that are beyond your control. Alright? Frank hesitates -- deep in thought. And then-- George Fowler comes out of the back room and takes a seat the bar, totally oblivious to what’s going on...
Excuse me... Frank stands up and charges across the room. The stranger watches, confused by his sudden departure...

Frank grabs Charlie’s empty BEER GLASS and hurls it right into George’s face. He looks up, stunned-- Frank knocks two of his teeth out with the first blow. Th second bruises a kidney and the third cracks a rib... TOWNSPEOPLE flee from the eye of the storm..
The stranger watches the attack with a faint smile; as if suddenly recognizing a worthy opponent...
Tom steps forward, trying to restore order--

Frank! Frank! That’s enough! You’re killing him!  99. Frank slams George's face into the counter, shards of gla splinter his skin. George drops to the ground-- Frank bends over, about to lift him to his feet... ..+.-when he suddenly hears the click of a gun--
Goddamnit, Frank, I said enough! Frank looks up and sees Tom pointing a SHOTGUN at him fro across the room. His eyes fill with betrayal...and rage.
Back away. Now. Frank slowly approaches his friend--

You’re gonna shoot me, Tom? Or just arrest me? Tom peers over the shotgun as Frank takes a step closer; barrels now just inches from his chest. And then-- Frank snatches the gun out of Tom’s hands. Everyone gasps he opens the boxlock, letting the shells fall to the floo
You're not doing either today... (Quoting Tom from earlier) Now, why don’t you do what you’re good at, Sheriff...and stand aside. Frank throws the gun down and charges back across the roo
Sam, whiskey. The bartender sets a BOTTLE down. Frank picks it up...

head_text.subj: AT THE END OF THE BAR

text: George pulls himself to his feet. Blood pours down his fa blinding his vision. He slowly turns around... ...Frank smashes his face with the whiskey bottle! Glass shatters, the alcohol stinging like acid. George screams...and goes down for the count. But Frank is on top of him, punching and wailing, kicking stomping, beating this man within an inch of his life.  100.
The stranger glances around the saloon, assessing differe people's reactions. Some seem horrified. Others, inspired
Finally, Frank stops. Just short of murder. He grabs Geor by the collar and gets right in his face...
Look at me...this is what happens when you hurt women. Frank throws George back to the ground, then slowly turns around to face the lingering stranger--
You were saying? The stranger smiles. And picks up right where he left off
There’s no need for you to go and get the good people of this town hurt. All we want is the girl. Frank wipes the blood off his face, then--

You can’t have her. The stranger stares at Frank with a faint smile. There it The dye is cast. Frank Sullivan has crossed the Rubicon. The stranger glances at George writhing on the ground, th walks across the room...and disappears out the door.
The stranger looks up once more at the WWI banner. Then h turns and walks down the street...whistling the entire wa

Everyone stares at at Frank Sullivan-- He doesn’t ask for any help or offer any explanations. He just puts one foot in front of the other... .--and charges right out the front door. BEAT. Tom watches the door shut, then walks across the room and picks up his deputy’s TIN STAR. He wipes it with his thum  101. .-.the blood smears across the metal, leaving Tom Donovan stare at his own reflection in the brass-colored tin.
Sue looks up as Frank comes into the room. She sees the b on his shirt. Her eyes suddenly go wide--
What did you do?
You have to leave now...
Why? Are they coming?
No...they’re already here. Frank grabs Sue by the arm and pulls her to the door...
Frank, wait a minute. Frank... (Then, screaming) ...take your hands off me! Frank suddenly lets go. Sue looks at him, softly--

Sorry. Frank nods quietly, then glances at the girl; still aslee completely unaware of what this man is about to do for he SUE (CONT’D) Are you sure about this? Frank hesitates, then slowly shakes his head-- SUE (CONT’D) Then don’t. Please, just...don’t.
It’s too late. I’m sorry... Frank turns and heads for the door. Sue follows him, realizing she may never see him again--

I don’t understand...why is this your responsibility? Frank, stop! She grabs his arm, desperate to make him stay--  102. SUE (CONT’D) Tell me why! Why do you have to go out there and face this alone? Frank suddenly erupts, frustrated and out of time--

Goddamnit, because I don’t have a choice. Because there’s a chance I might be able to help someone tonight. And I have to go. Do you understand? I have to go. Sue slowly lets go of his arm. Frank stares at her for a moment, then nods at the young girl--
Push her away from the window before the fighting starts... And then he turns and walks down the hall...
Frank? (He stops, turns around) When it’s all over, I'll be here... (Softly) .--waiting. Frank slowly nods, then disappears down the stairs.

Frank comes outside into the cold night air, crunching gr beneath his boots as he walks down the empty street... He takes position behind a building and waits; his rifle trembling in his hands; his breathing deep and heavy... Frank Sullivan is afraid -- we can see it in his eyes.
Sue pushes the girl’s bed away from the window, then clos the shutters and leans against the wall. Her eyes close with dread. She slides down to the floor..
Reverend Farley kneels in the third row of his empty chur hands clasped together tightly in prayer...  103.
Tom comes inside, shaken and undone. He stares at his wif for a moment, then hears a soft clicking sound... Edward is standing across the room, loading a RIFLE--
What are you doing?
Were you and Mom going to ask about the limp in my step?
(Hesitates) I hadn’t noticed...
Sure you did. You both did. You just pretended not to. Tom steps forward, scared to know the answer--
Edward, I asked you a question... why are you loading that rifle? Edward slides a final round into the chamber and slams it home. He turns to face his father--
It was just outside Neuve Chapelle. I took a bullet in the thigh...
You never mentioned it in your letters.

There were a lot of things I didn’t mention in my letters... (Beat) There was a french family who gave me shelter. If the Germans had found me, that family would’ve been executed. I was a stranger to them just like this girl is a stranger to you ...and yet they risked their lives in order to save mine. Edward turns to leave, having made his point...  104.
Where are you going?
To do what I can... Tom pulls Edward back from the door--
No, damnit, you’re staying here! Your mother and I didn’t wait through that blasted war just to lose you in some street brawl!
Let go of me, I’m not a child--!
You're my child! Edward looks at his father, suddenly calm--

I know you’re afraid... (Beat) But I’m only alive because of people like Frank Sullivan. Tom's grip weakens and Edward pulls way. He glances at hi mother one last time, then opens the door...and leaves. Rosaleigh turns to Tom, frantic and undone--
Tom? Do something! Tom goes to the window and watches his son walk away. The takes out his deputy’s tin star...and stares at it once m
Charlie Foster and Ben Sanderford hover around George Fow crunching glass beneath their cautious footsteps...
Jesus Christ. That was the finest beating I ever saw.
Frank went too far. George didn’t deserve that... Eli Peterson suddenly steps forward--  105.

No, he deserved worse. And sooner. Any man lays a hand on his wife has it comin’. Call me old fashioned. TOWNSPEOPLE glance at each other quietly as Eli stares at blood-soaked man squirming on the floor--
My son-in-law is about to die alone in the street... (Then, softly) What have we become?

The stranger’s footsteps echo as he walks quietly along t train. He stops at the engine and slowly turns around... Then, suddenly-- The stranger stops whistling. On that signal, every single car door suddenly opens... FIFTY GANGSTERS step out into the night, dressed in BLACK COATS, dangling TOMMY GUNS like samurai swords...

Frank grips his gun tightly as he waits in the darkness. hears a faint rustling...and glances across the street-- Leonard Duschene is crouched in an alley, holding his rif Frank nods quietly. Leonard nods back. And then-- Movement from above suddenly catches Frank's eye... TOWNSPEOPLE are taking position to help in the fight-- ..-Charlie Foster throws a rifle up to Ben Sanderson, the climbs a fire escape to the top of the saloon... ..+.-BAR PATRONS take cover in the alleys... ..-Eli Peterson and the Civil War vets crouch along the rooftops, drawing their service revolvers one at a time.. ...-Tom and Edward Donovan stand side by side, each point rifle towards the darkness up ahead...

The town sits quietly beneath a brilliant FULL MOON, enjo its last few moments of peace and tranquility... Suddenly, the barrel of a TOMMY GUN dips into FRAME, foll by BLACK BOOTS and an army of dark TRENCH COATS...

Frank Sullivan sees the approaching shadows. He glances a the other TOWNSPEOPLE. They all take cover... The gangsters pass beneath the WWI BANNER, glancing up at quiet rooftops as they make their way into town... TOWNSPEOPLE grip their weapons, waiting for Frank’s move. Frank takes a deep breath as the shadows pass by. Finally steps into full view, takes aim...and pulls the trigger. A GANGSTER'S head explodes in a bright puff of red...
Sue looks up at the crack of Frank’s rifle. Outside, GUNF erupts. The terrifying rapid fire of TOMMY GUNS--

The WWI BANNER falls to the ground as MACHINE GUNS explod Frank and the TOWNSPEOPLE dive for cover as bullets slam buildings, splintering wood and shattering windows... The guns expel thousands of rounds, each with the power t cut a man’s body apart. But then the magazines empty... And the townspeople seize their moment-- They step out of hiding as the gangsters reload. Frank fi again, followed by Leonard, Tom, Eli, Charlie, and Ben-- Five gangsters fall as the rest dive for cover. They relo their TOMMY GUNS...and the bombardment continues--
QUICK INTERIOR SHOTS -- Sue, Rosaleigh, and Kay all dive cover as BULLETS hit their buildings...
SUPER WIDE SHOT -- PEOPLE who fled the town earlier stand in the distance, watching GUNFIRE light up their homes...
An aging CIVIL WAR VET is the first townsperson to die. H takes three shots in the torso and slumps over the roof..
A BAR PATRON takes a shot in the head...
Charlie and Ben stand up to shoot...
Tom and Edward takes turns covering and firing...
Leonard Duschene kills two gangsters from the alley, then gets driven back by a barrage of gunfire...

Frank dives behind a Model-T. Gunshots shatter the window Frank leans forward and fires beneath the engine. A GANGSTER’S shin explodes and he falls to the ground. Frank finishes him off with a shot to the head.

Sue crawls along the floor and peers out the window. Outs bodies fill the street as TOWNSPEOPLE take cover... Sue glances at the young girl, clearly conflicted. Outsid another TOWNSPERSON falls, wounded... Sue fills a BLACK MEDICAL BAG...and dashes out the door.

The stranger blasts away with his tommy gun as he walks d the street. Calm. Unafraid. Shielded by shadows. He shoots a CIVIL WAR VET. Then a BAR PATRON. Then a RANC on a ROOF. The stranger watches his body slump forward, falling four stories to the ground.
Sue comes outside and races down the alley. She kneels be the rancher as gunfire ricochets around them...
GANGSTERS step out into the street, clearly gaining groun TOWNSPEOPLE fall back, retreating for cover...
Sue dodges bullets as she darts between patients; doing whatever she can as the madness rages around her...
The stranger empties his gun and then signals for a cease fire. An eerie silence falls on the town... .-.except for faint cries of men in their death throes--

(Shouting) You hear that?! Nobody wants this! Just give us the girl!! There’s a thousand dollars for any man who tells us where she is! BAM! A GANGSTER takes a bullet in the head and falls to t ground. The stranger ducks as his men resume firing--
(Shouting) Keep your money! The stranger’s face hardens. He shouts to someone nearby-
Who’s got the grenades? QUICK SHOT -- Edward Donovan’s eyes go wide...
I do!
Use ‘em! GANGSTER #1 pulls the pin on a GRENADE and tosses it onto roof where Charlie and Ben are positioned! QUICK SHOT -- Edward screams, too late--
Get out of there!  109. BOOM!!! A giant EXPLOSION sends the two regulars to their maker. TOWNSPEOPLE lurch back, horrified--

The stranger smiles, then nods for his men to continue. T fire into buildings, shattering windows... Then they toss in grenades-- BOOM! BOOM! BOOM! The explosions rock the town; one of the buildings collap in flames. The TOMMY GUNS resume firing...
Tom screams to Edward as everyone dives for cover--
‘The hell are those things?!
Shoot ‘em as they throw!
What?!
Cover me! Edward stands to fire. Tom lays down some cover...
Gangster #1 pulls the pin of a GRENADE...
